content.story_intro: DarkSide ransomware, 5,500 miles pipeline offline, East Coast fuel crisis

steps.title: Critical Infrastructure Target
steps.content: Colonial Pipeline: 45% de combustible de East Coast US (gasolina, diesel, jet fuel). 5,500 miles desde Texas hasta NY. Single point of failure para East Coast.
steps.insight: Critical infrastructure = high-value target. Ransomware gangs know orgs will pay to restore service.

steps.title: Vector: VPN Password Leaked
steps.content: Mayo 2021. Attackers usaron leaked VPN password (dark web, credential dump anterior). No MFA en VPN. Acceso remoto → deploy DarkSide ransomware. IT systems cifrados.
steps.insight: Password reuse + no MFA = disaster. VPN sin MFA es puerta abierta.

steps.title: Shutdown Decision: 6 Days
steps.content: CEO decidió shutdown preventivo de pipeline completo. Temor: ransomware spread a OT systems (SCADA, control systems). Better safe than catastrophic failure. 6 días offline.
steps.insight: Containment > continuity cuando OT está en riesgo. Pipeline explosion sería peor que 6-day outage.

steps.title: Ransom: $4.4M Pagado
steps.content: Colonial pagó 75 Bitcoin ($4.4M) en horas. DarkSide entregó decryption key (lento, barely usable). FBI recuperó $2.3M después (seized DarkSide Bitcoin wallet).
steps.insight: Pagar ransom NO garantiza recovery rápido. Backups son mejor que decryption key.

steps.title: Impact: Fuel Panic
steps.content: East Coast panic buying. Gas stations sin combustible. Airlines cancelaron flights. Precios subieron 20%. $4.4M ransom < $100M+ en economic impact.
steps.insight: Ransomware en critical infrastructure tiene cascading effects. National security issue.

steps.title: Aftermath: Regulation
steps.content: TSA mandó cybersecurity requirements para pipelines. CISA guidance. DarkSide gang shutdown (pressure from Russia). Colonial CEO testified ante Congreso.
steps.insight: Major incidents drive regulation. OT security ahora mandatory, no optional.

back.definition: Antes del incident. IR plan, playbooks, tools, training. CSIRT team formado. Contact lists actualizadas. Backups tested. Incident categories defined.
back.example: Colonial faltó: VPN MFA, network segmentation (IT/OT), tested backups. Preparation gaps = longer recovery.

back.definition: Detectar incident. SIEM alerts, user reports, anomaly detection. Triage: severity, scope, type. Initial containment decisions.
back.example: Colonial: Detectó ransomware cuando systems started encrypting. Mean time to detect (MTTD): minutes to hours ideal. Faster detection = less damage.

back.definition: Stop spread. Short-term: isolate compromised systems. Long-term: patch, harden, monitor. Balance: containment vs business continuity.
back.example: Colonial: Shutdown entire pipeline (aggressive containment). Prevented OT compromise pero 6 days outage. Trade-off.

back.definition: Remove threat completely. Delete malware, close backdoors, patch vulnerabilities, rotate compromised credentials. Verify no persistence.
back.example: Colonial: Needed to ensure DarkSide removed from ALL systems antes de restart. Forensics to find all infected systems.

back.definition: Restore to normal operations. Rebuild systems, restore from backups, validation, gradual bring-up. Monitor closely for reinfection.
back.example: Colonial: Restore from backups + decryption key (slow). Gradual restart pipeline. 6 days total recovery time.

back.definition: Post-mortem. What went wrong? What went right? Update IR plan, implement fixes, train staff. Blameless culture.
back.example: Colonial post-mortem: Implement MFA on VPN, segment IT/OT, improve backups, test DR plan quarterly. Share lessons.

unlock_content.title: Hour 0-1
points: Isolate infected systems: Disconnect from network (unplug ethernet, disable WiFi)
DO NOT power off: RAM forensics needed. Disk encryption happens on shutdown.
Alert CSIRT: Activate incident response team
Notify management: C-suite needs to know ASAP
Preserve evidence: Take photos of ransom note, don't delete anything
Check backups: Are they accessible? Encrypted too?
unlock_content.bonus_fact: First hour is critical. Ransomware spreads via network. Isolation prevents lateral movement.

unlock_content.title: Hours 1-6
points: Identify ransomware variant: Check ransom note for indicators. ID Ransomware tool.
Determine patient zero: Which system infected first? How did it enter?
Map spread: Network traffic analysis. Which systems touched?
Check for exfiltration: Did attackers steal data? (Double extortion)
Legal counsel: Notify lawyers. Determine disclosure obligations.
Law enforcement: FBI, local cyber crime unit. IC3 complaint.
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Modern ransomware = double extortion. Encrypt + threaten to leak stolen data. Check for exfil.

unlock_content.title: Hours 6-24
points: Segment network: Block ransomware C2 domains. Contain affected VLANs.
Credential rotation: Change ALL passwords, especially admin accounts.
Patch vulnerabilities: Close entry point (e.g., VPN without MFA).
Remove malware: EDR tools, format infected systems if needed.
Verify clean: Scan entire network. Hunt for persistence mechanisms.
Decision point: Pay ransom or restore from backup?
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Colonial paid but also restored from backups. Decryption keys are often buggy/slow.

unlock_content.title: Days 1-7
points: Restore priority systems: Critical first, then tier 2, then tier 3.
Test thoroughly: Validate integrity. Ensure no reinfection.
Monitor closely: Enhanced logging. Watch for C2 beaconing.
Communication: Update stakeholders regularly. Transparency.
Document everything: Timeline, decisions made, costs incurred.
Business continuity: Manual workarounds while systems recover.
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Colonial took 6 days full recovery. Some orgs take weeks. Tested backups = faster recovery.

unlock_content.title: Week 2+
points: Post-mortem: Blameless review. What can improve?
Implement fixes: MFA, segmentation, backup improvements, EDR deployment.
Threat hunting: Look for other compromises we missed.
Update IR playbook: Incorporate lessons learned.
Training: Security awareness. Phishing simulation.
Insurance claim: Cyber insurance may cover ransom/recovery costs.
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Post-incident improvements prevent next attack. Colonial now has MFA, better segmentation, tested DR.

back.definition: Debate eterno. Pagar financia crime, no garantiza recovery, keys pueden fallar. No pagar = prolonged downtime, data loss. Decision business, no técnica.
back.example: Colonial pagó ($4.4M). Garmin pagó ($10M). Cities NO pagan (policy). FBI: Don't pay, pero entiende business reality. Average ransom 2024: $200K-$2M.

back.definition: Business model. Developers create ransomware, affiliates deploy it. Revenue split 70/30. Lowered barrier to entry. DarkSide, REvil, LockBit = RaaS.
back.example: Affiliate (low skill) buys access from initial access broker, deploys ransomware. Developer gets 30%, affiliate 70%. Professionalized cybercrime.

back.definition: Tactic 1: Encrypt data (traditional). Tactic 2: Exfiltrate data + threaten to publish. Pay or data leaks. Increases pressure to pay.
back.example: Ransomware gangs run 'leak sites'. Post stolen data if not paid. GDPR fines + reputation damage. 80%+ of ransomware now double extortion.

back.definition: Coverage para ransom payments, recovery costs, legal fees, notification costs, business interruption. Premiums rising 50%+ due to claims.
back.example: Colonial likely had insurance (paid $4.4M without flinching). Coverage $1M-$100M depending on size. Requires security controls (MFA, backups, EDR).

content.question: Colonial Pipeline: ¿Decision correcta shutdown entire pipeline?

options.feedback: Incorrecto. Ransomware en IT systems con potential spread a OT = catastrophic risk. Pipeline explosion > 6-day outage.

options.text: Sí, containment aggressive previno potential OT compromise y disaster físico
options.feedback: CORRECTO! IT systems infectados. Riesgo: ransomware spread a SCADA/OT systems que controlan pipeline físico. OT compromise = potential explosion, spills, safety hazards. 6-day shutdown (aggressive containment) < physical disaster. Better safe than sorry cuando vidas están en riesgo. Criticism: Debieron tener IT/OT segmentation para evitar esta decision.
Separate issue. Shutdown decision fue sobre containment. Ransom payment fue business decision. Ambos pueden ser justificados dado las circunstancias.
Incorrecto. Emergency containment no espera. CEO tiene authority para shutdown. FBI notificado después para investigation.
